0.1.1 üìò Course Overview
This course introduces the statistical foundations of experimental design and applied data analysis in the context of nutrigenomics.
Students will learn to manage, visualize, and analyze omics, clinical, and dietary data using R and reproducible workflows.


0.1.2 Topics

Introduction to Nutrigenomics ‚Äî study design and data types

Measures of Association

Data Reading and Cleaning in R

Multivariate Descriptive Statistics

Dimensionality Reduction and Clustering

Introduction to Systematic Reviews

Each topic includes lectures, practical labs, and problem sets.

title: Design of Experimental Studies and Statistics Applied to Nutrigenomics
text:
0.2 Description of the Evaluation Components

0.2.1 1. Expositive Seminar (30%)

Format: Group presentation in pairs or groups of three.

Objective: To present and discuss a specific topic related to experimental design, statistical modeling, or data analysis applied to nutrigenomics.

Evaluation criteria: Clarity, scientific accuracy, statistical interpretation, and ability to engage in discussion.

Date: December 4, 2025 (final class session).

Deliverables:

15-minute oral presentation.
Accompanying Quarto or R Markdown document with code and figures (submitted through the GitHub repository).




0.2.2 2. Practices (25%)

Format: Individual R exercises completed during the practical sessions (marked below as Practices).

Objective: To apply the statistical techniques discussed in class using real or synthetic omics, clinical, and dietary datasets.

Submission: Each student must upload the corresponding .R or .qmd file to their personal GitHub fork or send it through the course platform.



0.2.3 3. Final Exam (45%)

Format: Individual written and computational test.

Objective: To assess conceptual understanding and practical skills in the design and analysis of studies in nutrigenomics.

Date: January 21, 2026

Recovery Exam: February 13, 2026

Minimum mark required for validation: 4 (out of 10).

0.4 Additional Notes

Attendance to all lectures and practices is strongly recommended.
All R scripts and datasets will be available in the GitHub repository under /scripts and /data.
Students are encouraged to collaborate during practice sessions but must submit individual code unless otherwise specified.
The seminar is designed to promote teamwork and critical discussion of applied methods in nutrigenomics.



‚ÄúDesign is not just about data collection; it is about asking questions the data can truly answer.‚Äù
‚Äî Course motto

2.0.1 What is Nutrigenomics (Statistical View)
This chapter introduces nutrigenomics from a statistical perspective, motivates key experimental designs, and reviews the types of data used in this field. It concludes with practical guidance for setting up R and the course repository.
Nutrigenomics explores how dietary patterns influence gene expression, epigenetic marks, and metabolic outcomes. Statistically, we ask:
Main challenges: high dimensionality (p‚â´n), correlated predictors, measurement error in diet data, and causal inference vs.¬†association.

2.2 Homework: Study Design Classification and Critical Assessment
For each of the following studies or study types, complete the tasks below:

Classify the study according to the design type.
Identify the primary objective of the study.
Describe the target population.
Discuss at least one limitation of the study design in the context of nutrigenomics.
